I think the affection and trust growing between them will help him become more sure of himself and start to overcome those fears of rejection and of becoming a monster. 

And the stronger Fjord’s sense of self becomes the better, because I think the danger at this point is that the fact that his identity is still so unstable is what makes him so vulnerable to Uku’otoa. Although he might have good intentions at the moment, the power and strength Uk’otoa is offering are going to be hugely tempting to someone with such deep rooted insecurities and might lead Fjord down a darker path. 

So might Fjord yet be drawn to evil? Yes, it’s possible. Uk’otoa clearly is evil and he is very deliberately constructed to play into Fjord’s trauma and biggest weakness.

Is Fjord already evil? No, I would say absolutely not. He’s made mistakes, but I think the idea that he’s evil relies on him having a much surer concept of himself than he actually does. 

Fjord’s made mistakes, sure. But he’s still trying his hardest to be good, and not to be the monster he was told from earliest childhood that he is.
trail.content_abstract:
aka, a meta exploring Fjord’s identity and development.

(Full disclosure: this got a lot longer and more in depth than I initially intended, and is really really long - the final word count is 6,955 words. The TL;DR is I think there’s a lot of trauma going on in Fjord’s decision making that gets overlooked or misinterpreted as him having ulterior motives, and that Travis has a created a deeply nuanced and layered character, and it doesn’t get enough appreciation. My thanks to the Fjorester Fam Discord for all the long discussions about Fjord that helped inspire this, and to @mamzellecombeferre in particular for reading through it and providing extra insights.) Spoiler warning for the whole of C2!

It just kind of baffles me that so many people still think Fjord is shady or evil, despite knowing his backstory and having watching his arc, when from my perspective he’s been, or has tried to be, one of the most upfront members of the Nein but is struggling to process a lot of trauma - some residual from childhood, but he’s also been bouncing from traumatic incident to traumatic incident over the last few months. That trauma has led him to make some poor and impulsive decisions, but never with any kind of malice or ill intent. 

Fjord’s whole arc and character is, I would argue, about identity and in particular feeling the lack of it. From childhood Fjord has struggled with having any kind of solid internal concept of himself and has looked outside himself to try and build an identity. He’s grown up not even sure what half his bloodline is as we know from Episode 21:

Nott: What is the other half?

Yasha: You’re half-orc, but what’s the other half?

Fjord: Half-human, I’d assume.

Yasha and Beau: You’d assume?  

Fjord grew up in an orphanage with no knowledge of either of his parents - he knows one of them was an orc, but has had to guess and make assumptions about the other because he doesn’t know for certain. Right away there’s a disconnect from any sort of heritage; he’s grown up surrounded by humans, but doesn’t know for certain he has human blood to connect him to that culture and, besides, has been marginalised and othered by humans since childhood because of his appearance and obvious orc blood. 

Travis confirmed on Talks Machina after Episode 19 that Fjord has never met a full-blood orc (and was disappointed to miss the chance with the hermit they met on the way to Labenda), and Fjord explicitly says of his childhood “there weren’t any others like me,” meaning neither were there other half-orcs to bond with or form some kind of communal identity. He only has external perspectives, stereotypes and prejudice against orcs to rely on to inform his perception of that side of his bloodline. He says in Episode 16 when he admits to filing his tusks:

Fjord: I feel like it’s a trait that exemplifies the rougher side of my race.

He is extremely aware of the conception of orcs as something monstrous and evil and how that manifests in his physical appearance. In Episode 11, he tries to connect with Nott by saying he understands feeling insecure and having self-image issues, and they have this exchange:

Nott: But you’re pretty handsome for a half-monster thing. I think Jester likes you.

Fjord: You think so?

Nott: Yeah.

Fjord: Well, I didn’t always look like this.

Nott: What?

Fjord: I wasn’t always a handsome half-monster thing.

Nott: What did you used to be?

Fjord: A kid, just like anyone else.

Nott: Still a monster thing, though.

Fjord: Yeah.

Nott: Oh. Just a less handsome one.

He tries to push back a bit against the label of ‘monster thing’ - which, while not said with any malice Nott’s part very aptly demonstrates the ingrained prejudice as it strips him of any kind of personhood and relegates him to a thing - by saying he was just a kid, but he immediately caves and accepts the label when Nott repeats it.

summary: I was listening to Cr2 episode 7 (Hush) and there were a couple of Nott quotes that were noticeable in light of recent...
body:
I was listening to Cr2 episode 7 (Hush) and there were a couple of Nott quotes that were noticeable in light of recent events.

Nott: But there’s a child…I’m going to try to help the child. (During the first battle with gnolls)

Nott: You shouldn’t separate a mother and her child. (Just before the manticore fight)

There’s no way Sam was not building up to his sucker punch with these.

(Side note: I’m going off memory here, they’re probably slightly wrong)

tags: inspired by a walk to caesarea by hannah senesh
the italicized lines are those of the original poem
body:
A Walk To Exandria

Oh Lord, My God

An empty notebook page, a scrawl of words, why didn’t you come?, a sense memory of iron chains

I pray that these things never end

Miles of empty tunnel, tiny scars, an endless flask, tears, blood, pain, a coat on a grave

The sand and the sea

Their first time at the beach, gulls and crabs, meditation, pets, the sound of her voice, a moment of peace

The rush of the oceans

Pulling away from the waterspout, flipping an ocean, erupting from a pyramid, a man’s voice over a spell

The crash of the heavens

Escapes, ball lightning at the mast against an angel, the road to the city, a laugh that only she hears

The prayer of man

An underground temple, a family found, a handful of wandering destinies, a little blue tiefling with her traveler and her eight-way heart

tags: I don't know if I expressed this well
I have trouble writing about these two
but I have a lot of feelings about them!!
summary: I’m so fascinated by Jester and Nott’s relationship, both how it’s changed and how it’s stayed the same. How they both dote on...
body:
I’m so fascinated by Jester and Nott’s relationship, both how it’s changed and how it’s stayed the same. How they both dote on each other yet have this raucous friendship.

In the first couple of episodes, Jester is very protective of Nott. Nott explicitly introduces herself as a little girl and Jester treats her as such: she gives her the Blessing of the Trickster and has Nott steal from her (and compliments her even when Nott fails). More than (almost) everyone else in the party, Jester feels immediately responsible for Nott’s physical and emotional well-being, and Nott appears both surprised and grateful for this. As Beau points out, Nott isn’t actually that good at pretending to be a little girl (”little girls don’t tend to tell people they’re little girls”), but Nott is dedicated to this role for the protection it affords.

What’s interesting, though, is that Jester is also the first one to really treat Nott like an equal. When they play detectives, it’s not Jester indulging Nott like a younger sister — they’re both laughing, goofing off, and egging each other on. It’s no surprise that Jester becomes the first member of the Mighty Nein (besides Caleb) that Nott really likes, because she’s the first one that really sees her as a friend and a partner. (I’ve got to wonder if Jester was the first person in Nott/Veth’s two lives to treat her like that, as total equals, besides Yeza. Caleb sees himself as her protector, and she sees herself as his protector, but who else in Nott’s life has she been silly with?) 

As time goes on, both Jester’s doting and their shared silliness continue. There are instances in which Jester isn’t exactly condescending to Nott, but definitely shields her emotionally; she reassures her and gives her advice. For example, after Nott tells her (false) backstory in e19, Jester’s the first to suggest that the Mighty Nein could protect Nott if ever she returned to Felderwin and tells her that she doesn’t have to act like her tribe. Jester also physically protects Nott, most notably when they’re escaping the High Richter’s house. 

On the other hand, they also have plenty of moments where they’re two friends on the same wavelength: when they make up their dance together in Hupperdook, or in their prank the Platinum Sanctuary. Their friendship also evolves from goofy to close and meaningful. Jester, for instance, is easily the most receptive to Nott telling the group that she’s Caleb protector; she seems less surprised by Nott taking care of Caleb than the fact that Caleb used to be “a scared little boy,” and immediately feels protective over Caleb as well. They begin to truly understand each other, even though Jester occasionally assumes a more protective role.

A third dynamic comes into play in episode 41, when Jester asks Nott for boy advice. It starts off as Jester simply looking for friendly advice from an equal (she initially tries to find Beau for this), but it quickly becomes apparent that Nott has significantly more experience with romance than Jester and as she gives advice, it almost feels like she’s giving “the Talk.” From this moment, Nott takes on a more motherly attitude towards Jester — in taking the dragon hit for Jester, in trying to set Jester up with Fjord, in offering her money, and in her concern towards Jester’s closed-off upbringing in Nicodranas. Jester’s “thanks mom” might have been a joke, but it’s an indication that she appreciates Nott taking care of her.

The funny thing is, though: this new dynamic, where Nott dotes on Jester, doesn’t make the other two dynamics go away. The two of them still egg each other into trouble in e42 (where they break into Avantika’s room), and in e50, Jester once again shields Nott emotionally when relaying Yeza’s responses to Sending — she is very reluctant to tell Nott that Yeza may not be okay, and almost wants to protect Nott from the truth.

In short — Nott and Jester interact in three very different ways with each other, and it’s just… really cool. Somehow, they’re BOTH the mom friends and BOTH encourage each other to be silly. And despite its seeming contradictions, their dynamic totally makes sense. It’s pretty likely that Nott and Jester are around the same age (mid 20s), so why shouldn’t they act like goofy young adults together? But Nott also legitimately has way more life experience than Jester — like the real world, some 25-year olds are married, have a kid (and have died once), and some have just moved out from their mom’s house and have just had their first kiss. At the same time, Nott’s skittishness activates Jester’s protective nature, and Jester can’t help but dote on her scared friend. So they take turns caring for each other, and when they can be silly, they are.

They begin to truly understand each other, even though Jester occasionally assumes a more protective role.

A third dynamic comes into play in episode 41, when Jester asks Nott for boy advice. It starts off as Jester simply looking for friendly advice from an equal (she initially tries to find Beau for this), but it quickly becomes apparent that Nott has significantly more experience with romance than Jester and as she gives advice, it almost feels like she’s giving “the Talk.” From this moment, Nott takes on a more motherly attitude towards Jester — in taking the dragon hit for Jester, in trying to set Jester up with Fjord, in offering her money, and in her concern towards Jester’s closed-off upbringing in Nicodranas. Jester’s “thanks mom” might have been a joke, but it’s an indication that she appreciates Nott taking care of her.

The funny thing is, though: this new dynamic, where Nott dotes on Jester, doesn’t make the other two dynamics go away. The two of them still egg each other into trouble in e42 (where they break into Avantika’s room), and in e50, Jester once again shields Nott emotionally when relaying Yeza’s responses to Sending — she is very reluctant to tell Nott that Yeza may not be okay, and almost wants to protect Nott from the truth.

In short — Nott and Jester interact in three very different ways with each other, and it’s just… really cool. Somehow, they’re BOTH the mom friends and BOTH encourage each other to be silly. And despite its seeming contradictions, their dynamic totally makes sense. It’s pretty likely that Nott and Jester are around the same age (mid 20s), so why shouldn’t they act like goofy young adults together? But Nott also legitimately has way more life experience than Jester — like the real world, some 25-year olds are married, have a kid (and have died once), and some have just moved out from their mom’s house and have just had their first kiss. At the same time, Nott’s skittishness activates Jester’s protective nature, and Jester can’t help but dote on her scared friend. So they take turns caring for each other, and when they can be silly, they are.

summary: ⠀pjo au aka Beau has been a problem child for as long as she can remember. Long enough to get used to the disappointed looks...
body:
⠀pjo au aka Beau has been a problem child for as long as she can remember. Long enough to get used to the disappointed looks from teachers and the glares from her parents. She has an expulsion list five schools long and an “attitude problem” according to her counselors.


⠀Then she turns fifteen and starts her second high school, the prestigious (or pretentious if you ask her) Cobalt Soul Academy. She doesn’t even make it one full day before she finds out Zeenoth, the obnoxious hall monitor, is actually some freaky goat thing. She definitely blames him for the two of them being chased by terrifying birds with fucking spears for wings.


⠀From there it’s a blur until the camp, she thinks she punched some birds, if her bloody hands are anything to go by but she can’t be sure. She’s introduced to another weird animal dude (“centaur” comes Zeenoth’s long-suffering tone) named Chiron. Chiron tells her that unlike her asshole father, her mom is an asshole who happens to be a goddess. He doesn’t use the word asshole but she’s thinking it anyway. He also tells her that not all the shit that’s been happening to her for forever is her fault because apparently halfbloods are danger magnets. Beau can’t help but laugh, who thought putting them all in one place was a good idea then?


⠀The first person Chiron introduces her to, other than reintroducing Zeenoth as one of the camp’s many satyrs, is Jester.


–


⠀Jester is the longest staying occupant of the Hermes cabin despite not being a daughter of Hermes. She’s unclaimed and no matter how many times she asks Chiron or the satyrs for help figuring out her godly parent, they just tell her to look for the signs, even though she’s pretty sure she’s looked for all of them. Not to mention, she knows her parent could be any of them, any god who wouldn’t come down to spend time with her mama is pretty silly and there’s no way her godly parent is stupid.


⠀Even if she wants to know who her godly parent is, she does like the job staying in the Hermes cabin gives her, she gets to welcome all the new campers. Like Beau.


⠀Beau is old for a new camper, probably around Jester’s age, which is exciting but also weird. Her face seems to stuck in a perpetual expression of anger and she has these bright, blue eyes that feel like the stare right into you. Some of the Hermes cabin was already betting she was a daughter of Ares with a scowl like that. Jester disagrees, she thinks Beau is nice, she compliments Jester’s dyed blue hair and blushes when she says it kind of matches her eyes.

⠀

This is all I’ve written so far but uh I don’t know if I should write more? I just saw the pjo musical so I have inspo
